awd_titl_txt: Community-Engaged Engineering Interventions with Appalachian Youth
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by producing empirical findings and/or research tools that contribute to knowledge about which models and interventions with K-12 students and teachers are most likely to increase capacity in the STEM and STEM-cognate intensive workforce of the future. This project is focused on a collaborative design, implementation, and study of recurrent engineering-focused interventions with middle school youth in three rural and Appalachian communities. The intervention efforts will broaden middle schoolers' participation and understanding of what engineering is, what engineers do, and help dispel the notion that it is hard and requires a love of mathematics and science. The project has the potential for recruiting future engineers who are unaware of their abilities and career possibilities because of the rural Appalachian communities in which they live. Broadening participation in engineering remains a critical national priority and this project has the potential to prevent the loss of smart capable students from engineering education and career pathways. The proposed partnership with school educators and industry experts will established an open-source engineering outreach curriculum (iFixit) and facilitate regular in-class interventions throughout the academic year. 

The study design enables the examination of the participants and interventions across time and case-site contexts, where the data are collected at individual-level to look for changes over time while within-case and cross-case examination of the community-level impacts will be analyzed. The objective will be to achieve meaningful results of the two goals: Goal 1- to increase youth awareness of, interest in, and readiness for diverse engineering related careers and educational pathways which is a goal that hinges on a collaboratively designed and facilitated set of monthly interventions in a curricular setting and Goal 2- to build capacity for schools to sustainably integrate engineering skills and knowledge of diverse engineering-related careers and educational pathways aimed at both the individual-level with a focus on teachers as influential change makers as well as at the community-level focused on sustainable cross-sector collaborations. The project will offer in-school curriculum activities (interventions) six times per academic year in three similar rural communities in Virginia: 1) Bedford County Public Schools 2) Giles County Public Schools, and 3) Smyth County Public Schools. All case sites are located in rural areas or near Appalachia where there is limited industry, particularly advanced industry exposes students, parents, and educators to engineering careers. Leveraging local expertise is especially critical in this project because family pressures, cultural milieu, and preference for local, stable jobs play considerable roles in how Appalachian youth choose possible careers.

por.por_cntn:
This Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) project referred to as Virginia Tech Partnering with Educators and Engineers in Rural Schools (VT PEERS) focused on the collaborative design, implementation, and study of recurrent hands-on engineering activities with middle school youth in three rural communities in or near Appalachia. To achieve this aim, the team partnered with school educators and industry experts embedded in students' local communities to collectively develop curriculum to meet teacher-identified science standards and to facilitate regular in-class interventions throughout the academic year. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic interrupting the final stages of this work, we believe we have made significant contributions to research and practice.

As a whole, the project engaged 22 teachers of 6th-8th grade science classrooms and their 1900+ middle-school students across seven schools and involved 24 graduate students and 31 industry professional volunteers. Additional programmatic outcomes included sharing the curriculum developed via Virginia Department of Education's open educational resource platform, GoOpenVA, and also hosting Engineering Career Assemblies in the schools which involved an additional seven VT outreach organizations, three local extension offices, a local community college, two regional workforce development organizations, a manufacturing association, and a local physics enthusiast.

From a research perspective, the primary efforts included understanding: (1) student-level perceptions of engineering activities and careers; (2) teacher motivation, self-efficacy for integrating engineering activities, and pedagogical choice; and (3) collaborative processes in multi-stakeholder partnerships. As a result of this research, the project generated a dissertation and published several papers and conference proceedings broadly throughout engineering education, STEM outreach, and community-engagement forums with additional papers in progress and under review.  The project also served as a research and practice training ground for 4 PhD students in engineering education and lessons learned will continue to transfer as these students develop and enter the workforce.  

Select findings include the following:

To support middle-school teachers integrating engineering into science, engineering educators need to translate big aspirational ideas into concrete and specific outcomes and align them with teacher and district priorities. Throughout the project, we heard from teachers that simple and concrete statements (e.g., engineers work with many types of people to understand problems and create solutions) helped them feel more comfortable incorporating knowledge of engineering careers into their classes. Such statements also helped them realize they may have been teaching engineering-related concepts and ideas but may not have formally identified them as such.  This is particularly important in situations where the goal is to broaden conceptions of engineering work and who can do it rather than teach and test on specific engineering content knowledge (e.g., engineering design cycle).  Our project findings reinforce our belief that for middle school level settings, focusing on perceptions of engineering work and careers is more important to broadening participation goals than teaching specific engineering content knowledge. Further, these efforts must be well aligned with teacher and district priorities if teachers are to be supported and successful at sustainably integrating engineering into science courses. For example, teachers reported appreciating that project activities built on locally relevant examples and sought to engage students of all ability levels and that inquiry-based approaches aligned with district level priorities.   

Connecting teachers within and across districts and with regional industry partners through a supportive community of practice is a promising strategy for building capacity to integrate engineering into science. Teachers reported learning from one another, building self-confidence in their abilities, and feeling connected enough to reach out to one another with questions or opportunities through the program's activities. This was developed over time through regular engagements throughout the year (e.g., industry in classrooms with teachers) and intentional summer workshops all together where students were paid stipends for their curriculum development work with each other within and across districts. Our findings align with existing professional development literature suggesting that the ability to connect and reflect with peers supports teachers in being creative and internalizing new teaching practices.

School-university-industry collaboration is an emergent, dynamic, and negotiated process across organizations but enacted by individuals and their relationships.  Based on analysis of interviews of all stakeholders (e.g., teachers, school administrators, industry, university affiliates), we discovered that perceptions of the partnership broadly and individual roles specifically varied as the project changed and grew over time. Individuals enacting the partnership ultimately navigate conflicting demands between their daily responsibilities and the demands of the collaborative partnership. Factors such as the personal motivations of teachers, the culture of the school or industry partner organization, and the degree of alignment between individual and collaboration goals and demands all serve to amplify or mitigate the tensions felt by individuals.
